questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents with complaints of excessive bleeding during her periods and increasing fatigue and cold extremities. Laboratory investigations reveal a Hb of 7gm/dL. In this patient with anemia, which of the following would be reduced?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Total arterial oxygen content
Oxygen content = (Hb in gm/dL X 1.34 X %saturation) + (Po2 in mm Hg X 0.003mL/dL/mm Hg)
If there is a decrease in Hb, the arterial O2 content of the blood will also be reduced. Oxygen extraction by the tissues increases to compensate for the reduced oxygen delivery to the tissues. Arterial O2, dissolved oxygen and the percentage saturation of hemoglobin with oxygen are all normal in anemia.

questions.text: A 35-year old woman visits her family physician. She has a mean arterial pressure of 105 mm Hg and a heart rate of 74 beats/min. further tests by the cardiologist reveal that the patient has a moderate aortic stenosis. Which of the following will be expected in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

↓ Pulse pressure, ↓ stroke volume In aortic stenosis, the stroke volume decreases. Decrease in stroke volume results in a decrease in systolic pressure and decrease in pulse pressure. The two determinants of pulse pressure are stroke volume and arterial compliance.

questions.text: Shown are the changes in secretion of three hormones, atrial natriuretic peptide, renin and aldosterone during immersion in water up to the neck. Which of the following is true?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Immersion in water up to the neck counteracts the effect of gravity on the circulation and increases the central venous pressure and consequently the atrial pressure. This in turn stimulates the atrial stretch receptors, which increase secretion of ANP and decrease secretion of ADH. 
Immersion in water increases the renal afferent arteriolar pressure which decreases the secretion of renin and aldosterone.
Conversely, on rising from the supine to the standing position there is a decrease in the central venous pressure and a small but appreciable decrease in ANP.

choices.text: Hypoxia induced vasoconstriction of pulmonary capillaries
Increased pressure in the pulmonary capillary beds
Disruption of the endothelial barrier resulting in leakage of fluid and proteins into the alveoli
Hypoxia causing vasodilation of pulmonary capillaries resulting in increased fluid formation

questions.text:
A 65-year-old avid male hiker, resident of Manali (at 5000 ft) was hiking in Sikkim with two companions. They hiked to Nathula in Sikkim at 12,000 ft in one day.  He suddenly complained of extreme tiredness, light headedness, dizziness, difficulty in breathing. He began coughing and complained of tightness in the chest. He was taken to the emergency services of a local hospital. The examination revealed respiratory rate of 32 per min, heart rate of 125/min, bp 180/100 mm Hg, bluish discoloration of fingertips, crackles and wheeze on the right lower lobe. His X-ray chest was done and is shown:-
 
Which of the following is not a possible reason for the man’s condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Hypoxia causing vasodilation of pulmonary capillaries resulting in increased fluid formation

The proposed mechanism for development of HAPE is uneven hypoxia-induced vasoconstriction resulting in increased pressures in capillary beds, subsequent fluid shifts, and vascular leakage. Disruption of the endothelial barrier results in fluid, proteins, and even hemorrhage into alveolar spaces. On a molecular level, the proposed mechanisms for the development of pulmonary edema at altitude include the nitric oxide pathway, the renin-angiotensin system, heat shock protein, pulmonary surfactant proteins, and hypoxia inducible factor.

questions.text: Destruction of the supraoptic nuclei of the brain will produce which of the following changes in urinary volume and concentration? (Assume that fluid intake equals fluid loss.)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Increased urinary volume, decreased urinary osmolality 

• Destruction of the supraoptic nuclei eliminates antidiuretic hormone (ADH) production. 

• ADH controls reabsorption of 23-27L of water in the collecting ducts 

• In complete absence of ADH, the collecting ducts of the kidney are impermeable to water and therefore all of the fluid passing through the distal convoluted tubule, about 20 L of hypotonic fluid per day, is excreted in the urine.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is a cyclin-dependent kinase (CDK) inhibitor that works in combination with endocrine therapy for HR-positive breast cancer?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Palbociclib

Explanation:
Palbociclib is a selective inhibitor of cyclin-dependent kinases 4 and 6 (CDK4/6). In hormone receptor-positive (HR-positive) breast cancer, it is commonly used in combination with endocrine therapies, such as letrozole or fulvestrant, to enhance treatment efficacy. By inhibiting CDK4/6, palbociclib prevents the phosphorylation of the retinoblastoma protein (Rb), leading to cell cycle arrest in the G1 phase and thereby inhibiting cancer cell proliferation. 
 Lapatinib: A dual tyrosine kinase inhibitor targeting both HER2 and EGFR, used in HER2-positive breast cancer.
Everolimus: An mTOR inhibitor that can be used in combination with endocrine therapy for HR-positive breast cancer, but it is not a CDK inhibitor.
Imatinib: A tyrosine kinase inhibitor primarily used in chronic myelogenous leukemia and gastrointestinal stromal tumors, not in breast cancer.

questions.text: Which of the following is the α4β7 integrin blockier used in the treatment of moderate to severe Crohn's disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Vedolizumab.

Vedolizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically targets the α4β7 integrin, inhibiting its interaction with mucosal addressin cell adhesion molecule-1 (MAdCAM-1). This action prevents the migration of inflammatory T lymphocytes into the gastrointestinal tract, thereby reducing inflammation in conditions like moderate to severe Crohn's disease. 
The other options are biologic agents used in inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) but have different mechanisms of action:
 Ustekinumab: A monoclonal antibody that targets interleukin-12 and interleukin-23, inhibiting the inflammatory process in IBD.
Natalizumab: A monoclonal antibody that targets the α4 integrin, inhibiting its interaction with both MAdCAM-1 and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 (VCAM-1). While effective in Crohn's disease, it is associated with a risk of progressive multifocal leukoencephalopathy (PML) and is generally reserved for patients who have failed other therapies. 
Tofacitinib: An oral Janus kinase (JAK) inhibitor that interferes with the signaling of multiple pro-inflammatory cytokines.

questions.text: A 62-year-old male with a history of ischemic heart disease is prescribed clopidogrel. Which of the following is the most common mechanism of resistance to this drug?
questions.solution:

Explanation: Clopidogrel is a prodrug that requires activation by CYP2C19. Variants of CYP2C19 that reduce enzyme activity can result in inadequate activation of the drug and resistance to its antiplatelet effects.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs, when combined with an SSRI, has the greatest risk of causing serotonin syndrome?

questions.text:

3.    Tumarkin's theory postulates an intratympanic negative middle ear pressure with collapse of the ear drum.

1,2,3,4

Option 3

•    Enzymatic factors, and putrefying chronic infection are the major causes.

questions.text: True regarding pseudohypoparathyroidism include all except:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Pseudohypoparathyroidism is genetic disorder characterized by symptoms and signs of hypoparathyroidism, typically in association with distinctive skeletal and developmental defects. The hypoparathyroidism is due to a deficient end-organ response to PTH. Hyperplasia of the parathyroid, a response to hormone resistance, causes elevation of PTH levels. 
Most patients show characteristic features of Albright dystrophy, consisting of short stature, round face, skeletal anomalies (brachydactyly), and heterotopic calcification. Patients have low calcium and high phosphate levels, as with true hypoparathyroidism. PTH levels, however, are elevated, reflecting resistance to hormone action.

•    Paraneoplastic syndromes are classified as metabolic, neuromuscular, connective tissue, dermatologic, and vascular.

questions.text: Which of the following breast implant is associated with higher risk of Anaplastic Large cell lymphoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)


Breast implant–associated anaplastic large cell lymphoma (BIA-ALCL) is a new provisional category in the 2016 World Health Organization (WHO) classification of lymphoid neoplasms,
median time of presentation is 10 years after implant insertion.
Main presentation is breast implant effusion or mass
Etiological hypothesis is it is due to activation of T cells reacting to bacterial biofilm arising in breast implants 
The disease shares similar immunopathologic characteristics with systemic and cutaneous anaplastic lymphoma kinase (ALK)–negative anaplastic large cell lymphoma (ALCL), with densely positive CD30 expression and negative ALK expression.
The majority of patients with the peri-implant effusion subtype have indolent disease and a good outcome, as opposed to the poorer-prognosis mass-forming or advanced-stage subtype. Unlike with other lymphomas, surgical excision is recommended as first-line (and curative) therapy in most cases of BIA-ALCL, with systemic therapy reserved for mass-forming disease, distant disease, and relapsed or refractory disease.

questions.text: Best investigation to detect prostate secondaries is?
questions.solution:

The sensitivity and specificity of PSA values is not very high due to lot of inter and intra-individual variations. Prostate specific membrane antigen (PSMA is a peptidase and a more robust surface biomarkers. Prostate-specific membrane antigen (PSMA) is a cell surface protein expressed abundantly in Prostate Cancer cells.
studies have shown a strong correlation between PSMA, stage of disease and Gleason's score. Hormone refractory cancers also show high PSMA and high PSMA is an independent marker of disease recurrence.

questions.text: A patient developed a nodular lesion with central telangiectasia over the nose. What is the diagnosis of this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)


Basal-cell carcinoma (BCC), also known as basal-cell cancer, is the most common type of skin cancer.It often appears as a painless raised area of skin, which may be shiny with small blood vessels running over it; or it may present as a raised area with ulceration. Basal-cell cancer grows slowly and can damage the tissue around it but is unlikely to spread to distant areas or to result in death. Option D. Keratoacanthoma (KA) is a common low-grade (unlikely to metastasize or invade) rapidly-growing skin tumour that is believed to originate from the hair follicle (pilosebaceous unit) and can resemble squamous cell carcinoma. The defining characteristic of a keratoacanthoma is that it is dome-shaped, symmetrical, surrounded by a smooth wall of inflamed skin, and capped with keratin scales and debris. It grows rapidly, reaching a large size within days or weeks, and if untreated for months will almost always starve itself of nourishment, necrose (die), slough, and heal with scarring

questions.text: Which sign has been shown in the figure
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Trousseau sign of latent tetany is a medical sign observed in patients with low calcium. From 1 to 4 percent of normal patients will test positive for Trousseau's sign of latent tetany. This sign may be positive before other manifestations of hypocalcemia such as hyperreflexia and tetany, as such it is generally believed to be more sensitive (94%) than the Chvostek sign (29%) for hypocalcemia. To elicit the sign, a blood pressure cuff is placed around the arm and inflated to a pressure greater than the systolic blood pressure and held in place for 3 minutes. This will occlude the brachial artery. In the absence of blood flow, the patient's hypocalcemia and subsequent neuromuscular irritability will induce spasm of the muscles of the hand and forearm. The wrist and metacarpophalangeal joints flex, the DIP and PIP joints extend, and the f ingers adduct. Option B. The Chvostek sign is a clinical sign of existing nerve hyperexcitability (tetany) seen in hypocalcemia. It refers to an abnormal reaction to the stimulation of the facial nerve. When the facial nerve is tapped in front of tragus the facial muscles on the same side of the face will contract momentarily (typically a twitch of the nose or lips) because of hypocalcemia (i.e. from hypoparathyroidism, pseudohypoparathyroidism, hypovitaminosis D) with resultant hyperexcitability of nerves. Option C. Troisier’s sign is enlarged left supraclavicular lymph node seen in intra abdominal malignancies Option D. Trousseau Syndrome is migratory thrombophlebitis seen in patients with intra abdominal malignancies. Most commonly associated with pancreatic Ca.

questions.text: If bleeding continues to come even after performing the following Maneuver what is the source of the bleed ?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The Pringle maneuver is a surgical maneuver used in some abdominal operations. A large atraumatic hemostat is used to clamp the hepatoduodenal ligament (free border of the lesser omentum) interrupting the flow of blood through the hepatic artery and the portal vein and thus helping to control bleeding from the liver. More commonly, in the absence of soft clamp, manual compression of the hepatoduodenal ligament is performed. Should bleeding continue, it is likely that the inferior vena cava or the hepatic vein were also traumatised. If bleeding continues, a variation in arterial blood flow may be present.

questions.text: Distributive shock is described by all of the following patterns of cardio- vascular responses except?

Distributive shock is characterized by ↓ BP (SBP <90 mm Hg) due to a severe reduction in systemic vascular resistance (SVR), with normal or ↑CO. 
•    Septic shock and anaphylactic shock are two common types of distributive shock. 
•    There is ↓ in venous tone and subsequent pooling of blood in venous capacitance vessels, and loss of intravascular volume into the interstitium due to increased capillary permeability.
•    Extremities are warm with bounding pulses and increased pulse pressure.

Atracurium

•    Atracurium undergoes organ-independent Hofmann elimination, making it suitable for patients with hepatic or renal impairment. 
•    It is metabolized by ester hydrolysis and is not dependent on hepatic function for metabolism or elimination.

questions.text: A 55-year-old female patient undergoing laparoscopic cholecystectomy under general anesthesia suddenly develops masseter muscle rigidity and a rapid increase in end-tidal CO2 (EtCO2) to 70 mmHg. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Administer intravenous dantrolene

•    The sudden development of masseter muscle rigidity and a rapid increase in EtCO2 is highly suggestive of malignant hyperthermia. 
•    The immediate treatment is the administration of intravenous dantrolene, a muscle relaxant specifically used to treat this life-threatening condition.

questions.text: During a resuscitation attempt, a patient in ventricular fibrillation (VF) is being defibrillated. After delivering the first shock, what should be the next immediate action?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Resume chest compressions immediately  
•    After delivering a shock for ventricular fibrillation, the next immediate step is to resume chest compressions without checking for a pulse or performing a rhythm check. 
•    High-quality chest compressions are crucial to maintain circulation while waiting to see if the shock was successful.

questions.text: A middle aged man suddenly becomes detached, and starts writing poems and stories, although it couldn’t be understood by anyone because of language and context was also not rational. Most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:

Schizophrenia
The clinical sign described is “Neologism” which is most likely seen in schizophrenia.

choices.text: Anticholinergic medications may alleviate his symptoms

Short-term memory is often impaired, with sparing of remote memory
Possible etiologies include infection, trauma, or polypharmacy

questions.text: A 78-year-old male has been hospitalized for the past 3 days after undergoing a revision left total hip replacement. Over the past several hours, the nursing staff reports that the patient has exhibited fluctuating periods of intermittent drowsiness and confusion where he has been speaking to non-existent visitors in his hospital room. The patient's daughter is present at bedside and reports that the patient lives alone and successfully manages his own affairs without assistance. Which of the following is most likely true of this patient's current condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


This patient's presentation is most consistent with delirium, which has numerous potential etiologies including infection, surgery or other trauma, or pharmacologic side effects. 

Acute onset of symptoms, fluctuating level of consciousness, and presence of visual hallucinations favor a diagnosis of delirium over dementia. Additionally, sleep-wake cycle disturbance is a prominent feature of delirium. Delirium is reversible, while dementia, by contrast, is often irreversible and is typically a diagnosis of exclusion confirmed by histology on autopsy. Clinically, patients with dementia show gradual decline in cognition with preservation of level of consciousness. Additional findings in dementia include aphasia, apraxia, agnosia, behavioral or personality changes, and short-term memory impairment with sparing of remote memory.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents to your office complaining of right arm numbness and weakness. Her past medical history is unremarkable. Her family history, however, is significant for the unexpected death of both her parents at age 59 in a motor vehicle accident last week. On physical exam, her bicep, brachioradialis, and patellar reflexes are 2+ bilaterally. CNS imaging shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Conversion Disorder
This patient is most likely suffering from conversion disorder. The lack of findings on physical exam and imaging along with a recent history of psychological trauma support this diagnosis.

Conversion disorder is one of the somatoform disorders, a category of illnesses in which physical symptoms occur without any identifiable physical cause. More specifically, conversion disorder is characterized by motor or sensory symptoms, most often following an acute psychological stressor. Conversion disorder cannot refer solely to pain or sexual dysfunction. Conversion disorder is most common in women.

questions.text: A 22-year-old female presents to your clinic for evaluation of "skin problems." She complains of severe acne and "spots" all over her face that have persisted for the last 8 years, despite innumerable creams and lotions. She reports spending several hours every morning using make-up just to go outside. She wishes to learn about cosmetic procedures or surgeries that could solve her problem. While you perceive her concern for her skin to be genuine, upon examination, you note a healthy-appearing, well-nourished female with a normal complexion, minimal acne and sparse freckles on the nasal bridge. You calculate her BMI to be 21. In addition to making a diagnosis, this patient should be screened for which disorder?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Major Depressive Disorder
This patient's preoccupation with an imagined deficit in the appearance of a body part is consistent with body dysmorphic disorder (BDD). While BDD is clinically distinct from other disorders, there is a high rate of comorbid clinical depression and suicidality. 

BDD is a somatoform disorder that causes clinically significant stress, impairment, and dysfunction. The preoccupation with an imagined defect is not explained by any other psychiatric disorder. Patients often seek aesthetic or cosmetic procedures which rarely serve as an effective treatment. The disease distribution is equally split between male and female patients.

questions.text: A case of resistant schizophrenia was prescribed on Tab. Clozapine. Weekly ANC and TLC were done. After 7 months of starting treatment, ANC was 1112/mm3. Next step of management is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Solution: 

Clozapine:

●    Most effective antipsychotic

●    Does not cause EPS as clozapine shows antipsychotic action at 40% D2 blockade

●    Useful in Tardive Dyskinesia

●    Broadest action antipsychotic

›    Acts on multiple receptors like D2>D1 , D3, D4, α1, 

›    Also acts on 5HT2C receptors → metabolic side effects

›    5HT2A action → antipsychotic action

●    It has anti-suicidal action

●    For clinical action, blood levels of clozapine should be >350 mg/mL

●    Side effects of clozapine:

›    m/c- sedation (H1 blockade)

›    Hypersalivation (= Sialorrhea)- due to M4 agonism and α2 antagonism

›    Anticholinergic side effects like constipation (M1/M3 antagonism)

›    Hypotension (α blockade)

›    Metabolic syndrome including weight gain, type II DM and obesity ( 5HT2C blockade)

›    Lowers seizure threshold →⸫ increased seizure risk (Dose dependent side effect)

›    Fever 

›    Myocarditis

›    Thromboembolism

›    Agranulocytosis: Dose independent (idiosyncratic)

▪    Hence requires TLC/ANC monitoring

▪    1st 6 months- weekly

▪    Afterwards- biweekly

▪    If TLC <3000/mm3 or ANC <1500/mm3 then STOP CLOZAPINE

●    C/I to clozapine:

›    H/o bone marrow disease

›    TLC <3500/mm3

›    H/o agranulocytosis on clozapine

›    Concomitant drugs causing agranulocytosis like Carbamazepine

●    Lithium + clozapine – can cause delirium →⸫ not given together

Reference: Kaplan & Sadock’s Pocket Handbook of Psychiatric Drug Treatment, 7th edition; Page 224-225

questions.text: Which one of the following manoeuvres is not used to treat shoulder dystocia?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Fundal pressure


Episiotomy is needed in shoulder dystocia for the ease of manoeuvres. Hyperflexion at the hip joint is the earliest manoeuvre; it is called as Mc Robert’s manoeuvre. Supra pubic pressure is given. Fundal pressure is not allowed. Knee-hand position is called as Gaskin method. This method increases the AP diameter and helps in delivering shoulder dystocia.

questions.text: A woman is getting 3 uterine contractions per 10 minutes. The fetus is in cephalic presentation and the head is not engaged. On vaginal examination, the cervical dilatation is 7 cm. questions.text: A 17-year-old male with AIDS presents with worsening exertional dyspnea, fever, and a nonproductive cough. His temperature is 102 F, heart rate 120 beats/min, and respiratory rate 19. A physical exam reveals mild crackles and rhonchi bilaterally. A chest x-ray shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates. He has no known drug allergies. What is the best initial treatment?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

Intravenous corticosteroids followed by IV trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole
Corticosteroids decrease mortality in patients with severe Pneumocystis
jiroveci pneumonia (PCP). Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole is the drug of choice, but pentamidine is used for those with sulfa allergy. Levofloxacin does not cover PCP. However, if there are infiltrates, it can be added for possible bacterial pneumonia. Adjunctive corticosteroids can decrease the inflammatory response associated with PCP. Also, they can reduce the decline of oxygenation and reduce the incidence of respiratory failure.

questions.text: A 1-year old boy presents with a persistent cough for the past 5 days. He has had several episodes of pneumonia and upper respiratory infections since he was born. He also has several skin infections. He is in the 10th percentile for weight and 5th percentile for height, but at birth, he was in the 50th percentile. A dihydrorhodamine test is abnormal and peripheral blood smear does not indicate hemolytic anemia. What is the most likely cause of this patient’s disease?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Deficiency in NADPH oxidase
Patients with chronic granulomatous disease (CGD) have an NADPH
oxidase deficiency, which makes them susceptible to recurrent infections,
typically of the respiratory tract.
At the cellular level, CGD can be diagnosed by measuring the capacity of
phagocytic leucocytes to form superoxide or hydrogen peroxide.
Neutrophilic granulocytes are usually used to detect NADPH oxidase
activation in the cells. NADPH oxidase assays include cytochrome c
reduction assay and the nitroblue tetrazolium slide assay, both of which
measure superoxide. Other assays exist to measure hydrogen peroxide
including the dihydrorhodamine-1,2, 3 (DHR) assay, and the hydrogen
peroxide (H2O2) or peroxidase activity assay. An abnormal
dihydrorhodamine test is significant for a CGD diagnosis.
While clinical history may help indicate the patient’s genetic inheritance
pattern, genetic testing is available to identify genetic mutations.

questions.text:
A 5-day-old female neonate is brought to the office in response to a call from the state laboratory reporting a thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) level higher than 200 mIU/L (normal <30 mIU/L) on her newborn screen. The neonate was born via uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery at 40 weeks’ gestation with a birthweight of 3.5 kg. Her mother took levothyroxine for Hashimoto thyroiditis and prenatal vitamins during pregnancy. The neonate has been breastfeeding well on demand. Her vital signs are normal. She has mild jaundice and a small, reducible umbilical hernia. Her thyroid does not appear enlarged. The physical examination findings are otherwise normal. Confirmatory thyroid function tests show a TSH of 520 mIU/L (normal 0.6-5.6 mIU/L) and a free thyroxine of 0.5 ng/dL (6.4 pmol/L; normal 1.2-3.4 ng/dL [15.4-43.7 pmol/L]).
Of the following, the MOST likely cause of this neonate’s laboratory findings is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)


The neonate in the vignette has congenital hypothyroidism with a markedly elevated thyroidstimulating hormone (TSH) level. The most likely cause is thyroid dysgenesis, which is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in the United States. The term “thyroid dysgenesis” includes the lack of or incomplete development of the thyroid gland as well as ectopic thyroid tissue. Ectopic thyroid tissue, which does not function normally, may be found anywhere along the path of embryologic migration from the base of the tongue (lingual thyroid) to its normal position in the neck.

questions.text:
A 2-year-old boy's parents are concerned about significant speech delay. He exhibits unusual dysmorphology, including malar and zygomatic hypoplasia with downslanting palpebral fissures; prominent nose; significant micrognathia and retrognathia; small, posteriorly rotated, and malformed ears; and lower eyelid colobomas with absent eyelashes. His father has similar dysmorphology.
Of the following, the MOST likely reason for this boy's speech delay is
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The boy in the vignette has Treacher Collins syndrome (TCS). Among patients with TCS, 40% to 50% will have conductive hearing loss because of underlying hypoplasia of the middle ear cavities and malformation of the ossicles. Inner ear anatomy is typically normal so sensorineural hearing loss is not usually seen. Less commonly, children with TCS will have a cleft palate or choanal stenosis/atresia which could also affect hearing.
